title: James Kwesi Appiah
text:
James Kwesi Appiah (born 30 June 1960), also known as Akwasi Appiah, is a Ghanaian <a href="association%20football">football</a> coach and former player who played as a <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29%23Full-back">left back</a>. He is currently the head coach of Kenpong Football Academy.
Early life and education.
Appiah was born on 30 June 1960 in Kumasi. He attended <a href="Opoku%20Ware%20School">Opoku Ware School</a> (OWASS) for his secondary school education.
Club career.
Appiah, a left back, played club football for Prestea Mine Stars between 1982 and 1983, before joining <a href="Asante%20Kotoko%20F.C.">Asante Kotoko</a>, playing for them between 1983 and 1993.
International career.
Appiah played for the <a href="Ghana%20national%20football%20team">Ghanaian national team</a> between 1982 and 1992, appearing in two <a href="FIFA%20World%20Cup">FIFA World Cup</a> qualifying matches; he also <a href="Captain%20%28association%20football%29">captained</a> the team. Appiah was part of the 1982 squad that won the <a href="1982%20African%20Cup%20of%20Nations">1982 African Cup of Nations</a>.
Coaching career.
Between 1992 and 1995 Appiah served as the assistant coach for his former club Asante Kotoko including deputizing under <a href="Malik%20Jabir">Malik Jabir</a>. He was subsequently promoted to serve in the role of head coach from 1995 to 1996. He served as a coach as part of the technical team of <a href="Fred%20Osam-Duodu">Fred Osam-Duodu</a> when he served as Head coach of the Ghana national team from 2000 to 2001.
He has received technical training from English clubs <a href="Manchester%20City%20F.C.">Manchester City</a>, and <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool</a>.
James Kwesi Appiah was Ghana's assistant coach between 2007 and 2012.
Appiah was coach of <a href="Ghana%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">Ghana U23</a> as they won the <a href="Football%20at%20the%202011%20All-Africa%20Games%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20tournament">2011 All-Africa Games</a>.
He was appointed as the Head coach of the <a href="Ghana%20national%20football%20team">Ghanaian national team</a> in April 2012, describing himself as "the underdog" in the process. His Ghana team qualified for the <a href="2014%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2014 World Cup</a> in Brazil, making him the first black African coach to take the country to the World Cup. He was given a new two-year contract in May 2014. After the country exited the World Cup in the group stages, Appiah defended his team.
He left his position as Ghana manager by mutual consent in September 2014.
He became manager of <a href="Sudan">Sudan</a>ese club <a href="Al%20Khartoum%20SC">Al Khartoum</a> in December 2014.
In April 2017 he was re-appointed as the coach of the Ghana national team, replacing former <a href="Chelsea%20F.C.">Chelsea</a> manager <a href="Avram%20Grant">Avram Grant</a>. He was sacked in January 2020.
In July 2021, he was appointed as the head coach of Kenpong Football Academy.
